Jason Rogers wrote:
> 
> If you know what node is changing (which you should) and what the new value
> is supposed to be (which you should), you can just very simply do the
> calculation, create a MockNode in your test that contains this new value and
> assert that the two are equal.  This presumes that the calculate method is
> already tested and working properly.
> 
> But that begs the question, if the only functionality of the state change
> method is to forward a call to some other objects calculation method, is it
> necessary to test the method in the TreeHolder class?

If the forwarding is anything but very very simple, I prefer to test it.
You can test (a) if the correct set of nodes has been chosen for
forwarding (b) if the correct method in the nodes is called. IMO this
holds enough potential for (future) failure. 
To be frank, I personally test even the most trivial delegation method.
With those tests in my back I haven't got to add many tests during
refactoring. Adding lots of tests when refactoring breaks my flow.

Johannes
